~$355 million to upgrade our water infrastructure 🚰

1328053118484025344.text: In too many communities – especially in communities of color and Indigenous communities – people are still struggling to breathe on high pollution days. Pollution still poisons the air we breathe, the water we drink and the food we put on the table.

1328053117544517638.text:
The Clean Air Act has stood the test of time because it created an adaptable roadmap to ensuring every American has an essential right—clean air to breathe.

But while our nation enjoys cleaner air than we did 30 years ago, our work to ensure #CleanAirForAll is far from over.

1328053116634353669.text:
The worsening environmental and public health crises all around us were impossible to ignore—they galvanized bipartisan momentum.

Congress mustered the courage and resolve to meet our nation’s air quality crisis with a response commensurate with the risks it posed.

1328053115669639173.text:
It was clear that our nation was facing an air quality crisis:

Industrial pollution formed clouds of toxic soot.

Acid rain fell from our skies.

Smog suffocated our communities.

Mercury, lead and arsenic polluted our air, water and food.

The ozone layer was rapidly depleting.

1328053114583347202.text:
Despite the difficulty, division, complexity and fear of costs, 400 representatives and 89 senators sent the Clean Air Act Amendments of 1990 to Republican President George H.W. Bush's desk.

Sweeping, progressive reforms were signed into law with overwhelming bipartisan support.

1328053113572503558.text:
In 1990, I had the privilege of working alongside the late Chairman John Dingell of the House @EnergyCommerce Committee.

As Chairman Dingell said at the time, clean air was "one of the most difficult, divisive, complex, costly and important issues" Congress ever had to confront.

1328053112544911360.text:
Today we celebrate the 30th anniversary of the Clean Air Act Amendments of 1990.

We can be hopeful about the prospects for meaningful action that meets the challenges of our day. That’s what today reminds us.

1246461384327643139.text: For our small state, the @USS_Delaware is more than a @USNavy submarine. 1246461382553411584.text: When I learned the @USS_Delaware was initially postponed due to health concerns related to #COVID19, I sat down with @Nick_Ciolino to talk about how this vessel came to bear the “Delaware” moniker. Listen here: https://t.co/9yAIOGOuHg

We honored a new generation of sailors preparing to take USS Delaware through its sea trials and protect our democracy. https://t.co/armstYyRjc

1246461374026452992.text:
But first, a little history. Did you know that Delaware’s naval history dates back to the Revolutionary War?
 
The Delaware Bay, just off the coast of Lewes, served as the staging ground for the Continental Navy’s first marine mission in 1776.

1246461371933491200.text:
Still, the first @USNavy ship to be named after the First State since 1923, the @USS_Delaware, has been commissioned today for active service and will soon begin to patrol the seas in defense of our nation out of the Port of Wilmington. 
 
That is worth celebrating.

1244001783921487873.text: Today, Martha and I are praying for Carolyn, their daughters Callie, Katie and Sarah, and the entire Coburn family. The world has lost a good man today. May God bless and keep him.

1244001782885494787.text: To say that Tom’s unwavering beliefs infuriated those who disagreed would be an understatement. He was famously stubborn and there was no shortage of folks maddened by his hardline stances. Still, he showed us that you can disagree with people, but still get along with them.

1244001782033985537.text: The result was lasting solutions to strengthen our nation's cyber defenses, bolster @USPS, increase transparency, safeguard taxpayer dollars and combat waste, fraud and abuse. Many people liked to refer to Tom as 'Dr. No,' but he and I were often able to find a way to yes.

1244001780771491841.text: To many, he was known as Dr. Coburn. But, to me, he was my fellow TC and my partner for a number of years on @HSGAC. We did not agree on everything, or even most things. 1243197217789349888.text:
To me, this issue is a matter of fairness.

1243197216786808833.text: Just like states across the country, the District of Columbia needs resources and funding from the federal government to effectively mitigate the spread of #COVID19 and protect its taxpaying residents.

1192194453978697734.text:
We’ve asked whistleblowers to be brave and speak out against wrongdoing, even if doing so comes with great personal or professional costs.

Now, members of Congress should be brave enough to speak out and say that the bullying of this whistleblower is wrong.

1192194451961208833.text:
Protecting the rights of whistleblowers has historically garnered bipartisan support.

What has changed?

1192194448987492357.text: Even my colleague Rand Paul has said that whistleblowers should be able to report wrongdoing “without repercussions.” https://t.co/KmVzSL8qUj

1192194441311870976.text: My Republican colleague Joni Ernst has called for “appropriate protection from retaliation” for whistleblowers. https://t.co/TMZY2ylXlV

1192194434143834115.text: My Republican colleague Susan Collins has fought for protection of whistleblowers as early as 2012, indicating that federal workers should have “peace of mind that if they speak out, they will be protected.” https://t.co/6a8sNk58Wp

1192194424224321536.text: Just this year, John Boozman, another member of the bipartisan Whistleblower Protection Caucus, said that he’s committed to promoting a culture that supports brave whistleblowers and prevents retaliation against those who come forward. https://t.co/njuJVGDqHF

1192194417064628224.text:
And so has my friend Thom Tillis who also serves on the Senate Whistleblower Protection Caucus with me. He 
 has encouraged bipartisan initiatives that “preserve the liberties of [whistleblowers] who bring professional and ethical misconduct to light.” https://t.co/JrXGfrVRT5

1192194404242644998.text: Ron Johnson, who also serves on the Whistleblower Protection Caucus and as Chairman of Senate Homeland Security and Governmental Affairs Committee, has been an advocate for whistleblowers for years. In 2015, he said “[Whistleblowers] deserve all the protection from retaliation…” https://t.co/CoSrnLekci

1192194395669508098.text: Long-time advocate for whistleblowers and Chairman of the Whistleblower Protection Caucus, Chuck Grassley from Iowa, has pushed to strengthen protections for whistleblowers who are “fearful of retaliation.” https://t.co/JPktDQfgrN

1192194387570253824.text:
THREAD: Members of Congress -- on both sides of the aisle -- have said to those serving in our government: if you see misconduct, say something. And we will make sure you are protected.

It's one of the ways we have worked to root out waste, fraud, and abuse in our institutions.

It remains my hope that throughout this process we will continue upholding our sworn oaths and follow the facts on behalf of Americans — wherever they may lead.

1182742243444215808.text: If the Trump Administration continues to stonewall, it is my hope that the courts force the Administration to turn over pertinent information so the House can do its job. I will not prejudge the outcome of the House’s process, but they must be able to move forward.

1182742242437541888.text: Right now, the Trump Administration is stonewalling and trying to stop the House — part of a coequal branch of our government — from doing its job during this impeachment inquiry.

1182742240986386432.text:
Next, if the House votes to indict – it’s up to us in the Senate to do our jobs. That evidence is presented to members of the Senate who act as jurors.

If we get to that point, I am wholly prepared to do my job.

1182742239992303624.text: First, the House of Representatives acts a grand jury – it gathers information, or the evidence, related to the alleged possible misdeed. If the House finds there is sufficient evidence, then members of the House would vote on the articles of impeachment.

1182742238981447682.text: In that Constitution, first ratified by the state of Delaware, our Founding Fathers devised a process in case the President of our country is suspected to be involved in inappropriate or unlawful behavior.

1182742238016757760.text: We can’t go more than a few hours without more news emerging about the President’s dealings and the dealings of those around him. 1166075645056757763.text: My bipartisan bill, America’s Transportation Infrastructure Act, includes the first-ever climate title in a surface transportation reauthorization bill. It invests $10 billion to enhance the resilience of roadways and bridges to extreme weather & reduce greenhouse gas emissions.

1166075128486268928.text: For as long as I can remember, Congress has passed multi-year transportation bills that fund improvements to our roads, highways and bridges. But what we’ve never really done in those bills is address the impacts of climate change on our infrastructure.

1166073677202513921.text:
We need to ensure our roadways and bridges are designed and built to withstand climate impacts like extreme weather and sea level rise. 

We also need to reduce the harmful greenhouse gas emissions helping to fuel the climate crisis.

1166073389989187584.text: Delaware is the lowest-lying state in America. Our state is sinking and the seas are rising—we can see the impacts of climate change all around us.

1165755008455008256.text: Today, I join Delawareans and Americans across the country to reflect on John McCain’s legacy and to heed @cindymccain’s call to restore civility in politics in his honor. #ActsofCivility

1165754825805586439.text: There will never be another man like John, but I hope that, in our own way, we can strive to be more like him. Americans need to see that in their leaders now more than ever.

1165754751767797761.text: Courage is keeping out of step when everyone else is marching to the wrong tune. That’s the type of courage John displayed throughout his life.

1165754557428883456.text: I will always cherish our important work together — especially our work to recover the missing remains of our fallen soldiers and our efforts to help normalize relations between the U.S. and Vietnam.
